Interval stats

Jay Hesselberth

November 14 2016

Interval statistics

valr can be used to explore relationships between sets of intervals.

library(valr)
library(tidyverse)

# load repeats and genes
rpts <- read_bed(valr_example('hg19.rmsk.chr22.bed.gz'), n_fields = 6) 
gens <- read_bed(valr_example('hg19.refGene.chr22.bed.gz'), n_fields = 12)

# load chrom sizes
chrs <- read_genome(valr_example('hg19.chrom.sizes.gz'))

# create 1bp intervalss representing transcription start sites
tss <- mutate(gens,
              .start = ifelse(strand == '+', start, end),
              .end = start + 1) %>%
  select(chrom, start = .start, end = .end, name)

tss
#> # A tibble: 1,267 × 4
#>    chrom    start      end         name
#>    <chr>    <int>    <dbl>        <chr>
#> 1  chr22 16193009 16150529    NR_122113
#> 2  chr22 16157078 16157079    NR_133911
#> 3  chr22 16162065 16162066    NR_073459
#> 4  chr22 16162065 16162066    NR_073460
#> 5  chr22 16231289 16199674    NR_132385
#> 6  chr22 16287937 16256332 NM_001136213
#> 7  chr22 16274608 16274609    NR_046571
#> 8  chr22 16449804 16448824 NM_001005239
#> 9  chr22 17073700 17071648    NM_014406
#> 10 chr22 17082800 17082801    NR_001591
#> # ... with 1,257 more rows

Generate statistics

Here is a function that takes the following inputs:

  • x: tbl of intervals
  • y: tbl of intervals
  • genome: tbl of chrom sizes
  • grp: grouping variables
  • type: name of data type e.g. ‘obs’ or ‘shuf’. appears as a new column in the result.
gen_stats <- function(x, y, genome, grp, type = NA) {
  group_by_(x, .dots = grp) %>%
    do(reldist = bed_reldist(., y, detail = TRUE) %>% select(.value = .reldist),
       absdist = bed_absdist(., y, genome) %>% select(.value = .absdist)) %>%
    gather_('stat', 'value', setdiff(names(.), list(grp))) %>%
    mutate(type = type)
} 

shfs <- bed_shuffle(rpts, chrs, within = TRUE)

obs_stats <- gen_stats(rpts, tss, chrs, 'name', 'obs')
shf_stats <- gen_stats(shfs, tss, chrs, 'name', 'shuf')

res <- bind_rows(obs_stats, shf_stats) %>%
  unnest(value) %>% 
  group_by(name, stat, type) %>%
  mutate(.id = row_number()) %>%
  spread(type, .value)

res
#> Source: local data frame [19,658 x 5]
#> Groups: name, stat [2,102]
#> 
#>     name    stat   .id     obs     shuf
#> *  <chr>   <chr> <int>   <dbl>    <dbl>
#> 1   (A)n absdist     1 5120782 12994665
#> 2   (A)n absdist     2  226966 10142569
#> 3   (A)n absdist     3   40872  9324589
#> 4   (A)n absdist     4    6419  8497577
#> 5   (A)n absdist     5   41316  7408638
#> 6   (A)n absdist     6   22519  6009524
#> 7   (A)n absdist     7   14407  4678515
#> 8   (A)n absdist     8    9467  2833472
#> 9   (A)n absdist     9   26145  2116237
#> 10  (A)n absdist    10  134007    38887
#> # ... with 19,648 more rows

# now filter the results to remove x/y's with less than 2 obs
n_obs <- res %>% summarize(max_id = max(.id)) %>% filter(max_id > 10)
res <- res %>% left_join(n_obs, by = c('name', 'stat')) %>% na.omit()

Empirical p-values with ks.test()

pvals <- res %>% do(broom::tidy(ks.test(.$obs, .$shuf)))

pvals <- arrange(pvals, p.value)

pvals
#> Source: local data frame [244 x 6]
#> Groups: name, stat [244]
#> 
#>      name    stat statistic      p.value
#>     <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>        <dbl>
#> 1  AluSx1 absdist 0.3434066 0.000000e+00
#> 2    MIRb absdist 0.3107639 0.000000e+00
#> 3   AluJb absdist 0.3690037 2.220446e-16
#> 4   AluSz absdist 0.3552124 1.287859e-14
#> 5   AluSx absdist 0.2976190 2.374767e-13
#> 6    AluY absdist 0.3024691 2.676748e-13
#> 7   AluJr absdist 0.3518519 4.871659e-12
#> 8    MIRc absdist 0.3117871 1.576239e-11
#> 9   AluJo absdist 0.3461538 2.999678e-11
#> 10 AluSq2 absdist 0.3395349 3.440226e-11
#> # ... with 234 more rows, and 2 more variables: method <fctr>,
#> #   alternative <fctr>

eCDFs

group_by(data, type) %>%
  ggplot(., aes(x = x)) +
  stat_ecdf(color = type) + 
  facet_grid(~ rpt)
